In Star Wars. The millennium falcon. Travels faster than light speed. Because it harnesses The power of a solar phenomenon. Called a solar flare.

The first part of the plasma ribbon acting as something that clears the path for the back half. Possibly taken advantage of the thermodynamics of repulsive radioactive effects. To produce a solar flare effect.
But sustained thrust in this manner. Would be incredibly difficult. Solar flares are generally short lived although frequent.
Containing the fuel source inside something so small wouldn’t be possible for a sustained long duration flight.
It would take something much larger like a star destroyer. Which uses something like ion drive engines. Again the thrust to weight ratio. Makes it practically impossible to achieve with in a human life span. Which is why in the movies it cuts The scene with a blur of star lights. What they’re not showing or telling you in the movies. Is that there are hyper sleep chambers. On board of the millennium falcon. That it takes them hundreds if not thousands of years To reach their destination.
But for the movies. All for the sake of entertainment. It’s instantaneous.

Turning light into thrust therefore becomes exceedingly difficult. Unless it’s done inside a special chamber or vacuum tube. With a great amount of lost energy or trust. Like with an ion drive thruster. Which could get a close to light speed Eventually. If it had enough fuel and time to achieve the velocity. Which would probably take longer than a human life span.

So just to travel the speed of light. You would have to have something that travels ahead or faster than the ship. To clear the way.
One common hypothesis for faster than light travel. Is using a space tube. Which is like a subway tunnel created with a series of gates you pass through. That give a push or boost. But I think even then. It would be a massive undertaking. To string hyper gates across the universe or solar system.
Each gate would have to have a fixed position in perfect alignment. With the power of the sun focused into the hyper gate system.
This would get closer to real light speed. But the strain on the ship and therefore the people inside.
Could prove to be fatal. I think humans might be limited to slightly less than light speed travel personally. Because our mortal bodies or minds are not designed to deal with extreme cosmic forces.

Everything is done virtually by remote. The people are not actually physically there. Making warp speed possible. Because there are no organic living organisms involved. There's no way to "know" the answer but I really hope someone reading this is able to provide some intelligent, possibly even some educated information to clarify. I've asked this question on other platforms and got what I call the "religious responses". Stuff like "no because nothing can exceed the speed of light. That's what the good book of physics tells us and even though I can't explain why this entirely sensible assumption isn't possible, you don't question the almighty Albert Einstein. Amen".
But in a world filled with Newtonian Witnesses, Einstein opened his mind to accept that what physics knew as facts could be (and in the case of gravity, was) mistaken. I hate the word "impossible" or "can't" because it closes our minds to the possibilities. I look forward to reading the response from you nerds although it's likely to blow my mind if I can even understand it.

Two things:

First one is wormholes. They have a potential to allow travelling faster than light speed. Although, technically it wouldn't be travelling at light speed through space, but rather just bending space to the point where two places are connected via a "shortcut" and that shortcut has a shorter distance than the actual space would have normally.

Second: impulse. Specifically electron impulses. One example is for what I mean: if we talk with someone via Internet (facetime), how do we hear each other without delay? Since every sound you make gives an impulse to the connection (which is mainly through cable), the impulse has to travel at VERY least, from your position to the other. Now if you would stand next to each other, no problem. But if you talk with someone who is on the other side of the world, that's a different story. That distance takes light at least a noticeable amount of time, yet when talking, you don't hear it.
Btw from the microphone of your phone to the speaker of the other person's telephone, the impulse makes in summary 1-3 world round-trips. So my assumption up there was just minimal compared to what is actually happening. Sorry for not giving any sources, but if you want to, look up how the Internet basically works.

Ok. I have read "To Sleep In A Sea Of Stars" by Christopher Paolini. Amazing book 😀 Well, obviously it's a sci fi book, so not actual science. However, Paolini has always been great at doing research on topics before writing about them.

Paolini has in his book created a FTL drive for his ships (Faster Than Light). As I have understood the whole thing (as english is not my native language) the FTL drive creates a "bubble" around the ship (Paolini calls it a Markov bubble). Then the ship remains stationary within that bubble, but the space in front of the bubble is compressed and then behind the bubble the space is again expanded. So the ship itself remains stationary, while moving through space.

I have heard thise theories mentioned elsewhere as well, so I imagine that Paolini has too. Now, aside from the fact that we don't have the technology or any way of producing the energy needed for such thing, is it theoretically possible?

At the end of the book, Paolini has even made up some science papers explaining how it all works, but that went somewhat over my head. I read along in the book, while listening to it at the same time to improve my english.

I think you've done a video about this, but what about the Alcubierre warp drive?

For the uninitiated, this hypothetical drive encloses a 'bubble' of 'normal' spacetime between a trough and a peak of gravitationally warped spacetime. Our spacecraft, situated exactly between these two warped regions, stays in the center of that bubble. The trough is projected in front of the craft and the peak is projected behind. As these move, the craft also apparently moves. The kicker here is that there doesn't seem to be a speed limit in Einstein's equations for the movement of spacetime itself. Mass is not being moved; the spacetime in front of and behind the craft is being warped instead. Within its bubble, the apparent velocity of the craft and everything in the bubble is zero but, to an observer that is at rest relative to the craft, the craft has an apparent FTL velocity.

It is possible that the speed of light simply represents a boundary layer and spacetime behaves like a fluid. comment_text: It bothers me when I see people online write “so and so anime character is really strong/fast so they must be able to go faster than light”. There’s nothing wrong with applying science to works of fiction and I want the general public to be scientifically literate, but people don’t bother to do their research. Physics gets weird at the extremes of size and speed (quantum mechanics, relativity, etc.) that you can’t apply intuitive everyday physics. Any object with mass cannot travel through space faster than light because the energy used to accelerate the object increases its mass. We observe this in particle accelerators where the particle gains more mass instead of reaching or surpassing the speed of light. Only massless particles such as photons can travel at well... the speed of photons (light). Yeah, this stuff is not intuitive but nowadays you can watch a < 10 min summary video on YouTube to familiarize yourself with the subject. I wish that people would educate themselves so that they actually know what they are talking about.

I loooove your channel. "c" is poorly described as being the speed limit of the Universe. The better explanation is that c IS the speed of everything in the Universe unless the thing has (non-zero) rest mass. So, photons, gluons, gravitational waves are always traveling at c. Things made of hardons, like protons and neutrons, have rest mass, and, thus, move slower. So, a better concept is to start at c as the default speed of things - and, if something has mass, it moves by some proportion ( and relativistically ;) of course) slower than c. Yes, at some smaller and smaller speeds, things like friction, etc will then come into play more to slow things down. (0:08 better to use the term 'space-time' vs just 'space,' of course) [~ a physicist]

The speed of light is an absolute. The speed of light is @186,000 miles per second. However, it is possible to travel faster than the speed of light if you could figure out how to warp space before you. Suppose you were travelling at 93,000 miles per second (1/2 light speed), but if you could warp space before you so that 1 mile in 'regular' space = .1 mile in 'warped' space, then, while traveling at 93,000 miles per second, you could traverse space equaling  930,000 miles in a second. You would still be traveling at 93,000 miles per second, but the 'actual' distance traversed would be 930,000 miles. Perhaps, if you could warp space enough, you could create a wormhole, which would allow you to traverse a vast distance in no time at all, because the 'warp' would create a direct connection between point one and point two.

Yes, the spot would move faster than the speed of light if you define what the "move" and the "spot" actually are to make it travel faster than light. People are asking about concepts, not the known physics. It is like asking a biologist "If the fish could walk, could it run as well ?", but then you simply don't stick with the category of a question explaining that fish don't have legs, can't breathe the open-air and that concept of a fish is a relative concept since we know it is evolving. All we know is that it may become a snake-like creature, and no legs would appear at all! Perhaps the physics needs some evolving to do as well and perhaps the fish with legs is not the fish at all (but some kind of a lizard), but perhaps we don't know what the lizard is yet... That was the whole point of those questions, to show that perhaps we don't know everything and that there is a slight possibility transferring ourselves to any point in the universe that would seemingly go against the no-faster-than-light travel. I would love to know the set of laws and what would defy the current knowledge we have about the nature of the universe to make faster-than-light possible, and then perhaps, we could combine a hybrid hypothesis to test. Another approach would be to prove that there cannot exist an universe with anything that would travel faster than light... which I truly doubt given that we can come up with examples such as the spot of laser moving faster than light (which is already a simulation of a different kind of an Universe). I think that faster-than-light travel is possible but not probable, while we have to re-define the concept of a travel first. Perhaps it would mean entering or wrapping within another universe first (or making this one modular), and re-emerging ...

Baaaaaannnnttttt. I understand the easy for misconceptions that lead to incorrect conclusions about the speed of light. First, the speed of causality is what it is really needs to be called. Please refer to the experiments to slow light down to validate the difference between the "speed of light" and the speed of causality. Seriously, those are some really cool videos.

As for the speed of causality, the really insurmountable problem is how to detect something that moves faster than the speed of causality. There is no current method available to detect things at that speed, because as is stated in the video "the particles only go the speed of light". It is very much like trying to detect a missile traveling faster than the speed of sound using an automobile speedometer.

Now I am going to fault Veritasium here a bit. In covering of the laser shining on the moon, he correctly covers the photons are traveling at the speed of causality in a straight line from the laser source to the moon. However, there is the contribution of angular velocity, albeit extremely, ridiculously, ludicrously small in comparison to the speed of causality the photon is traveling at from the laser to the moon. Drawing a simple triangle of the vectors shows the resultant vector to be just a tiny smidgen faster than the speed of causality.

I am interested to see what comes out of the gravitational wave experiment. Since it did detect the gravitational wave back in 2017, will it lead to a method to detect stuff faster than the speed of causality?

Ok, it's 1850 and the question is: "Will humans ever build a flying machine?"  Humans didn't know how to build a flying machine in 1850 because they know nothing about aerodynamics.  The sentiment of the day is that a flying machine is heavier than air and will fall to the ground.  It's 1850 all over again and the answer to the FTL riddle is found in similar thought experiments (and real experiments) necessary to find an answer.  We know that the universe is expanding faster than light (and that's a fact)... so something does indeed travel faster than light.  The biggest impediment to finding an answer is assuming it has no answer.  That the speed of light is a constant just as gravity is a constant in building a flying machine.  Ok, 170 years later we know all the answers about a flying machine (even though we don't) and we are starting to come up with plausible theories about FLT.  My guess is that something is on the horizon (30 years or less) that will blow our concepts about the universe sky high.  But today we don't know what that is.

To really understand why you can't move faster than the speed of light (without manipulating spacetime), you need to understand that we do not live in a euclidian space (that is, our x, y, and z-axis of our surroundings are only an approximation of the universe); rather, we live in what is call minkowsky space, which involves two 45 degree 'light' cones on a space (x/c) horizontal axis and a time (t) vertical axis. These cones are called light cones because on their axis, you are travelling at the speed of light and are no longer experiencing time--a feat in which only massless particles are capable of.

If you add a y/c axis, you can see that it is like we are fallling down a hyperbolic paraboloid (the shape of a saddle), where we are at the saddle point (level point of the center of the saddle) at the present falling into the future. If you are experiencing the speed of light, you will find that you are no longer falling, yet not climbing the surface since that's impossible--you are constantly level; thus by not being able to fall, the time dilation works out so that you do not experience time whatsoever.

"Photons are limited to the speed of light due to a drag force they experience that scales with their cross-sectional area, velocity, and the density of an unseen particle that exists all around space (let's call it Dark Matter since that is the running name).

Due to photons being the reason other particles can move in general, this explains why "time" (the general measurement of rate of motion of particles in a given segment of 3D space, not a dimension) slows down closer to black holes (black hole = high gravity, high gravity well = more Dark Matter density closer you get to the center, thus "time" slows down at an exponential curve towards the center, and speeds up as you get away from it).

Speed is also relative. That is to say speed is based on a reference point. This reference point is completely arbitrary. I can have a train traveling at 30 mph. inside that train I can throw a ball in the same direction at 10mph. The ball is going 10mph in relative to the train. Simultaneously it is going at 40mph relative to the earth. The ball could be going at a infinite number of different speeds relative to other reference points in the universe as could the train and the Earth.

To break the speed of light you need only 2 ships that can travel at just over 0.5 the speed of light. For this example we will use two shops that can travel at 3/4 the speed of light. Ship A takes off away from Earth at 3/4 the speed of light in any direction. Ship B takes off in the opposite direction also at 3/4 the speed of light. From Earth each ship's "speed" is 3/4 light speed. From Each ship Earth's "speed" is 3/4 light speed. From each ship the other ship's "speed" is 1.5 times the speed of light. Light speed barrier broken.

People are genuinely confused about what 'the speed of light' means. For one thing, it isn't a 'speed' at all. That is, it isn't just a velocity through space. The 'speed of light' is in actuality the speed of causality through Time AND Space. The speed of causality for each and every person, atom, particle, photon, neutrino, wave... every single thing in our universe is always running at the speed of light in FOUR dimensions, not three. No slower, no faster. It's always exactly the speed of light. If you are standing still then your causality is still going at the speed of light on the Time axis. If you are observing something moving in space, then its causality vector is going at some velocity V through space but its rate of time (T) will be slower, such that the Time-Space vector itself remains going at exactly the speed of light.

I'm musing units a little, but that's the key point. In 4 dimensions, all vectors in our space-time are always exactly the same length, period. No shorter, no longer.

Now throw in special relativity, which is just a statement of the above. We can state that the speed of causality in four dimensions (the three dimensions of space + one dimension of time) is always constant. All experimental evidence points to it being a constant, and there is really an awful lot of that evidence. But how we MEASURE it is another problem entirely. What Einstein's special relativity says is that the above rules work for any observer in an inertial reference frame (that is, not undergoing acceleration). So if your measurement of causality is relative to your current position in space, then your measurement in space is that you are going a velocity of 0 in all three dimensions of space and thus your time axis must be going at the speed of light (that is, as fast as it is possible for time to go by any measurement you can make). If you measure the speed of an object flying past you, using your current position as the (0,0,0), then it will have a velocity vector in three dimensions and your observation of that object's clock will be slower, such that its causality vector in 4 dimensions is precisely the speed of light.

The confusion for most people is that they don't understand that 'time' is inexorably linked to velocity in space, and that both velocity and time can only be measured relative to something else. There is NO absolute notion of velocity or time in space.

So if we take the example in this video and just assume that the string can handle whatever forces we throw at it, the object at the end of the string still can't ever exceed the speed of light in terms of its measured velocity. What will happen instead is that as you throw more and more energy into the object to speed it up, as the object approaches the speed of light in terms of its velocity vector, where the energy will go instead of increasing its velocity further is into the TIME dimension of its vector. Your measurement of the object's clock will show that time is moving slower and slower for the object as its velocity measured relative to your finger gets closer and closer to the speed of light.

Derek does not state this directly, but basically when he talks about the amount of energy you have to put into the system to speed it up, that's where the energy is going ... into the TIME dimension for the object, and less and less of it is going into the three dimensions of space that govern its velocity.

The reality of this experiment is actually more complex than even that, because a rotating object or an object in an orbit does in fact experience a constant acceleration (and, as well, any object sitting in a gravity well also experiences an acceleration). Acceleration ALSO effects how time is perceived, and that is covered by Einstein's General Relativity. Unlike Special Relativity, actually trying to solve equations for General Relativity gets ridiculously complex very very quickly as the complexity of the system being calculated increases.

Even the ridiculous theories of attraction, at a sub matter level, revert to, or rely upon a pushing force. All of those theories are worthless compared to the “single sub matter particle model” of the universe. Which was proven, and was never explained away, it was forced away by laws and policy.

Sincerely,

William McCormick

All because we call it "speed of light". We should call it "universe's speed limit". It is natural for people to think "if this is the speed of light, why can't there be something else that has a different speed limit?". Isn't the speed of light faster than the speed of sound? Why can't there be something still faster? As it turns out the speed limit is that of the universe, and light happens to travel at that speed. Whenever we want something to go faster, a car, a plane, we try to make it lighter. Thus, with less effort we can reach higher speeds. Light is the "lightest" thing there is. Having no mass, according to F=ma or, in this case a=F/0 any force results in an infinite acceleration, even the slightest non-zero force gets light bouncing off like 'flubber', the fantastic substance in The Absent-minded Professor.
Still, as with 'absolute zero' in temperature where people asks whether we can make something even colder, saying 'absolute speed limit' might not make a lot of a difference, but at least it avoids pinning it to light.

the speed of light is slower than the speed of time. Just as the speed of velocity is slower than the speed of acceleration. Light is a function of time, and velocity is a function of acceleration. any constant variable that's that functions within a constraint whether physical or purely theoretical is by default slower or lesser than the function that it sits inside unless that function does nothing other than equalize the variqble... meaning multiply it by 1 and that's it. If the speed of light serves as a relative variable in the function of time, then time is the fastest thing in the universe because in a sense everything is always trying to catch up to it. It just so happens to be that light is the closest thing to time itself but it's still relatively slow compared to time.

Here's another way of putting it. What's a larger number than 9 trillion to the 9 trillion to the 9 trillion factorial factorial factorial factorial to the 9 trillion factorial? Well, infinity.... Infinity is not something we know about physically, but conceptually it's very real. Don't ask me why or how we are able to grasp ideas that don't exist within a material reality, because then we are having a philosophical and theological mud slinging fest within seconds. But this concept of infinity i suspect is very closely related to the concept of time in that on a fundemtbal level the two ideas have no objective limit, yet they are objectively functional in our understanding of everything else. In that sense, I would argue that time is the fastest thing I the universe, just as infinity is the largest number in the universe.

v>c is possible for example tachyons however there is not particular expirement for it,but they do not violate the lorentz factor,do they?here for example let's disccus about neutrinos,Before neutrinos were found to oscillate, they were generally assumed to be massless, propagating at the speed of light. According to the theory of special relativity, the question of neutrino velocity is closely related to their mass. If neutrinos are massless, they must travel at the speed of light. However, if they have mass, they cannot reach the speed of light.

Also some Lorentz-violating variants of quantum gravity might allow faster-than-light neutrinos. A comprehensive framework for Lorentz violations is the Standard-Model Extension (SME).

In the early 1980s, first measurements of neutrino speed were done using pulsed pion beams (produced by pulsed proton beams hitting a target). The pions decayed producing neutrinos, and the neutrino interactions observed within a time window in a detector at a distance were consistent with the speed of light. This measurement was repeated in 2007 using the MINOS detectors, which found the speed of 3 GeV neutrinos to be, at the 99% confidence level, in the range between 0.999976 c and 1.000126 c. The central value of 1.000051c is higher than the speed of light but is also consistent with a velocity of exactly c or even slightly less. This measurement set an upper bound on the mass of the muon neutrino of 50 MeV at 99% confidence

In the last example the final reasoning as to why it couldn't work seems flawed to me. The fact that the intermolecular forces giving the material it's strength are carried by photons isn't relevant to the problem. Yes, if the engine and tethers could be built to impossible specifications and if infinite energy could be put into the system the tip of the tether would be moving at the speed of light relative to the center of the machine, but no neighboring molecules in the tether would be moving at the speed of light relative to the other molecules. Therefore, this hypothetical tether could hold together even as light speeds.

This explanation for the impossibility of the machine also wouldn't work because since this tether would need practically infinite tensile strength, it would essentially be perfectly rigid which means that there would be no relative motion between molecules in the tether.

It's worth pointing out that it isn't really appropriate to discuss the motion of such distant galaxies with special relativity. When the expansion of space becomes significant, the problem can only really be analyzed with general relativity, in which "speed" isn't even defined globally. Locally, in any inertial (free-falling) reference frame, the speed of light is still c and everything travels at a speed less than c (except an isolated massless particle in free space). But globally, there is no speed of light, because there are no global inertial reference frames in GR.

Relative speed can't be more than C. Basically you can speed up as much as you like. We're already flying with our galaxy across the universe at a speed close to C. So if it was impossible to go faster than C, we wouldn't be able to speed up away from the center of the ex-big-boom more than for the rest of it. So if we're moving at C minus 5 meters/s fast, we would take infinite energy to go 5 meters/s in the same direction.

So... if we're moving at a speed close to C and we make a space ship and go somewhere at 1/2C, and then collect space junk, asteroids etc and build a new planet, we'll be on a planet that we AGAIN call 0. Then we build a new rocket on it and go somewhere. Repeat as many times as you want, you'll speed up a million times away from a 0 speed point to 1/2C in the same direction. So relatively to each new 0 point you'll gain 1/2C. 1000000/2C in sum. It won't take infinite energy either, it'll be 1mil x E necessary to gain 1/2C. So if it's true and we're limited by C, it's only relative. Like, at first we will go at 1/2C for Earth 1 and 0 for Earth 2. Then we speed up and to Earth 2 we go at 1/2C and like 0.75C for Earth 1. Then 0.5C for E3, 0.75C for E2 and 0.87C for E1. And so on.

Everything he says in this vid, is correct.

We tend to conceptualize the way that rigid bodies act, and what you can do with them; but in special relativity (SR),
there is no such thing as a rigid body!

And that is largely for the reasons he explains here.
For a body to be truly rigid, it must transmit any change in motion imposed on one part of it, to all its other parts, instantaneously!

And that, sir or madam, is impossible in SR!

Exceeding (or even reaching) the speed of light is impossible. However it might be possible to effectively reach and exceed light speed with a spacecraft. The craft itself would be immobile and stationary within its frame of reference. However, if the frame of reference is a bubble with space contracting on one side and expanding on the other, it might be possible to contract and expand space such that the bubble itself would travel faster than light, carrying the craft (which is motionless within the bubble) along with it. This is the basis of the Alcubierre Metric.

What limits the observable universe is precisely that: anything beyond the horizons of the observable universe is moving away from us, and the space between us and all that is beyond those horizons is in fact moving away from us at a speed greater than light. That is why there is a horizon of the observable universe.

There is a way. But it involves dark energy, with its infinite acceleration, or likewise, we could bend space so that we move a light year to the distance of a mile, effectively moving 1000's of times the speed of light.

There is one exception, so far as we know. It is known that the universe is expanding. In fact, the rate of expansion is increasing itself. Everything in the universe is moving away from each other. So far as we know, there is no upper limit to the rate. Remember, light is part of the universe, its limit does not apply to the universe itself. At a certain point, objects will be movign away from each other faster than the speed of light. What is most interesting about this notion, is that any electromagnetic wave (light for example) will be moving slower than the rate of the universe expanding. That means, at a certain point, all objects in the universe will be completely "out of range" of any other. If the earth still exists at that point, the inhabitants will think that the universe only contains the Earth.

"The speed of light is the speed limit of the universe." I'll keep this short, a speed is a relative number. For example, you are moving 50 km/h faster than the surface of this road. That is a relative number. If there is a "universal" speed limit, where is the reference point? What are we moving relative to for us to measure our speed?

Fact 1: If you launch from Earth in a magical space ship and accelerate to the relative speed of light (from Earth), nothing stops you from going faster because relative to yourself you are still thrusting yourself forwards at the same rate you were when you started.

Fact 2: Galaxies in our universe are moving away from our own galaxy at speeds greater than c. How would this be possible if the (relative) c was a magical speed limit? It's not, so this disproves the "Universal c speed limit" theory.

Correction 1: The carbon nano tube infinite-motor device he was talking about at the end of the video (ignoring the near-infinite forces involved) would be possible because, relative to the atoms, the atoms around it would be moving at low speeds. This would cause no problems.

I think, part of the issue is that with the Speed of Light, you simply have a lot of misconceptions surounding it. What the Theory of Relativity says, is that nothing with rest mass can reach the speed of light, like a ship - photons have no mass, only a relativistic mass, and thus they move at c. And nothing that contains actuall information and/or energy can be faster than c. Hypothetically, you can create certain objects, which are always moving faster than the speed of light, but those would travel back in time, which breaks physical laws. Those exist only in math. However, what is a lot more accurate, is to see the speed of light as the uper limit for causality. This limit isn't the speed of light because of photons or light, it's simply the speed limit for our universe. But space for example, can actually move faster than the speed of light. And this, can be even observed! So it's not like that it doesn't exist. Just not for everything.

Part of me is surprised he went with explaining how the tip of a very long swinging bar couldn't travel faster than light as being due to the force on the atoms that would make it up. Very interesting, but I believe it has long been known to theoretical physicists that even if you could somehow have a purely unbendable, unbreakable, indestructible very long rod, the tip of it would still "bend" and lag behind, due to length contraction and other relativistic effects. So even an infinitely strong pure solid rod, defined only by its mass and size and unconstrained by any constituent electrons or photons, still cannot exceed the speed of light if swung like some cosmic lever of Archimedes.

Also surprised that conservation of angular momentum was not mentioned in the example of the spinning Elon Musk whatever and the carbon nanotubes. If a compact thing is rotating, and then spreads itself out perpendicular to the axis of its rotation, then its rate of rotation is going to decrease. So unspooling two threads of carbon nanotube out of opposing ends is going to slow the rate of rotation. Maybe since the nanotubes are small molecules and the satellite is a large-ish macroscopic object this seems like it couldn't do much, and I'm tired and don't really care to do math to check it, but relativity would certainly confound it in one way if not another (again, probably without even having to analyze it on the basis of its atoms). Even though the nanotubes have a very small mass and the central spinning satellite has almost all of the mass, if it's spinning so fast the tips have relativistic speed (say 10% c) then probably almost all of the angular momentum of the system is going to be due to the ends of the tubes. For a less dramatic example, the Sun has 99% of the Solar System's mass, but the planets have 99% of the Solar System's angular momentum.

No observable mass retaliative to you can go faster than light, however an object with no relative frame of reference can go infinitely faster than 2.98x10^8, there is such an object that can in fact do this... space. It's actually easy to make something go faster than the speed of light. Just take a fast particle (like an energetic beta particle from a nuclear decay event) that's going most of the speed of light in a vacuum and make it pass through something like water where the speed of light is significantly slower.

And just like going faster than the speed of sound makes sound itself (a sonic boom), going faster than the speed of light makes light itself. It's called Cerenkov radiation and it's what causes the blue glow in a nuclear reactor.

Of course, that's playing fast and loose with the term "speed of light". What Derek was talking about was the speed of light in space (i.e. in a perfect vacuum), c, which is indeed the ultimate speed limit, so far as we can tell.

Hmmmm... well, the rule is that nothing can go faster than light. However, there's a little clever wordplay thing here... because NOTHING - i.e. SPACE - can go faster than light. In other words, you yourself may not be able to go faster than light, but SPACE can do whatever the hell it wants, because it's NOTHING. The key isn't to move YOUR SHIP to faster than light - it's to move the space AROUND your ship faster than light. You're not moving at FTL, but the space around you is.

Imagine space is an ocean and your ship is a surfer. First, we'll make the ocean "smooth" - no waves, no ripples, just a calm, smooth surface with no breeze to kick up any waves. For this demo, we'll set the speed of "light" at, let's say, 20 mph. On a still surface with no waves, the surfer can try all he wants to move at speeds greater than 20 mph, but he just can't. It's because the water resists his acceleration proportional to how quickly he's moving. Trying to accelerate to 20 mph or faster would require more energy than the surfer can exert, so he can't move faster than 20 mph.

Now we give the ocean "waves" that the surfer can "ride". All of a sudden, it's a different story. The surfer is now able to accelerate to speeds greater than 20 mph, but he's not putting in any energy to accelerate. Why is he able to move at that speed when, just before, we said that on a smooth surface he could not go faster than 20 mph or even reach that speed?

Simple, it's not himself that's accelerating him, it's the water. Remember, the SURFER can't move more than 20 mph, but the WATER isn't bound by those rules and can do what it wants. All the surfer has to do is pick an area with a wave - or, if he has enough energy, make his OWN wave - and ride that wave. That will accelerate him to a speed faster than "light" if light moves at 20 mph - but remember, he's not accelerating, it's the water around him accelerating him to that speed. All he's doing is riding the wave.

Every charged particle produces a magnetic force, a bump in the fabric of space that, in theory, spans the universe. The closer you are to the particle, the steeper the hill of the bump (or valley) becomes, and the farther away you are, the less steep it is and the less strong of a force you feel. But it never truly goes away, no matter how far away you are. If that charged particle changed, say, from having a negative charge to a positive charge, would something very very far away feel the effects instantaneously, or after the same amount of time that light takes to travel that same distance?
I feel like this is not really answerable with the amount of knowledge we have about the fabric of space itself, but I think it's an interesting idea. Hopefully I've conveyed it in an understandable way.

This is a great video.  I've got another proposal for you, however, that in principle could allow something to seem to go faster than the speed of light, but without violating any of the limitations as you described, even EM forces.  This is an idea Feynman was apparently playing around with shortly before he died.  He gave up on the idea because he couldn't come up with any means to test it.  However, the principles seem sound.  Here goes.  Feynman stated that there are amplitudes that exist for every particle to travel faster than the speed of light.  However, these amplitudes never emerge, and thus are never observed in reality because the amplitudes cancel out.  That doesn't mean they aren't real, however.  As an equivalent example, take optical grating.  In nature under typical conditions, you will never see a photon "bouncing" from areas of a mirror that are blocked from the direct light source.  However, by carefully removing areas of the reflective surface that cancel out the amplitudes for light to be returned from those areas actually causes these amplitudes to appear.  That is how we get holographs, like the 3-d picture on your common bank card.  So, then, what if it were possible to "grate" space/time in the same way?  In principle, you would be able to "remove" selected areas in front of the object you want to move in such a way that the object would be able to move through the remaining space much faster than the speed of light.  But of course, the kicker is that space/time is not a simple reflecting surface, and in fact in order to do this you would first have to establish that space/time was indeed quantized, and we aren't there yet.

The speed of light is only constant in a vacuum when observed within a specific gravitational field.  The speed of light itself isn't constant, everything that it interacts with changes its speed, including gravity. And if you follow the proposition that electrical charges are communicated by photons then the basis of all matter would be light itself.  Any matter potentially accelerated to light speed would become light itself because it would degenerate into its simplest form.  If all matter is made of light then the speed of light is relative to gravitational influences on the observer.  The observer would record the same speed as a data point on the moon as on the earth because the every atom of the observer's body and all test equipment would be subject to the same gravitational relativity.  The speed would record the same on the moon as on the Earth even though relative to each other they would be different.  In other words, every particle of everything that exists is already statically vibrating at the speed of light.  Everything is moving at the speed of light, however it isn't really the speed of light that is the constant but the vibrational frequency of photons throughout all of space and matter.  Which would also mean that time couldn't be physically traveled through because it doesn't physically exist.  We recognize time because we record the changes in the forms of matter all around us, and we can predict things based on the frequency of the repeating changes. But that makes time itself simply a recording of what exists, how it exists, when it changes and how often within the vibrational constant certain things occur. So history is a mystery unless you know where to look.

This video makes me think about a problem, I've wondered about for a long time. Maybe it would make for a great video explaination:

Described by special relativity, as objects move faster, so does time dilate differently compared to a motionless bystander. Now, concidering that this effect, although tiny, is actually measurable for gps satelites orbiting earth. So here is the conundrom:

Think of the propellar of a plane. Spinning at high rpms (I don't know how many) having a given diameter, the outermost part of the blade will reach tremendous speeds while the center will virtually not move at all. Lets put some numbers in the equation, realistic or not, the must be attainable in some scenario: Diameter of blade: 2,5 meter. RPM: 30000 - simple math tells me, that the outermost part of the blade moves at 14.130 km/h. Nowhere light speed, but fast enough to make time dilation measurable.

Now - If the outermost part moves faster through time than the center, even by a tiny amount, would the whole assembly not be... dismantled... or whatever?

First, let me start by saying that I understand that it is impossible to travel faster than light in a vacuum.

With that in mind, however, the speed of light is still relative to the observer. Since no two adjoining atoms would be anything approaching lightspeed, the photons carrying the electromagnetic charge which holds them together would still be able to flow easily from point to point. So even though the particles at the base of the tethers would be completely unable to communicate with those at the arms, they don't have to. They only have to interact with the atoms immediately beside them, who only have to interact with those immediately beside them, and so on and so forth. Assuming an elemental tether, the only way that it would snap would be if the orbital speed between the center of one atom and the center of the next one out were too great for them to interact, assuming we already have the tidal forces accounted for in building a sturdy enough, universe-thick tether.

There is actually a way to move faster than the speed of light. Simple shine a light into a black hole. Not even light is fast enough to escape a black hole due to its gravity, meaning that if an object "spawned" in the middle of one it would move faster than the speed of light to the center, however since it may need time to accelerate it may not actually reach that spped. However, if you shine light into one, not only will the object, the light itself, be moving at the speed of light, but once it passes the event horizon, since we shined it directly into one it would be moving in the same direction as the gravity, speeding it up past the speed of light.And we know that the gravitational strength of a black hole exerts a pull strong enough to outdo the speed of light, meaning it will speed it up instead of staying at the terminal velocity of the speed of light.

Exceeding the speed of light is actually rather simple.
One need only change the reference point of what that speed is.
While it's true that light travels 186,000mps in a vacuum, it is slower in other media, and in fact has been stopped by experimentation.
This means that every living creature has exceeded the speed of light in this reference point.
Alternatively, space dictates how fast light can travel, so if space is altered so the speed of light in that reference is faster, then exceeding the currently accepted speed would theoretically be possible.

No object can singularly move at the speed of light, although it's possible to create an entangled relation with a velocity greater that the speed of light.
How? Easy.
How do you measure speed?
Let's say you're a sprinter and you want to measure your speed. You set yourself at a starting position, wich could be a line marked on the ground called "start" (let's call that A) and then you run (let's call you B). The method by wich we measure your speed will be by calculating the velocity at wich B moves away from A (the Universe cares little if you call it the reverse, because WHO is really moving, A or B, is relative to the observer). So, to calculate a speed we need a relation between two points. Now, instead of having a stationary and a moving A and B, let's have two moving objects, still A and B, wich will run in oposite directions. Once they start, they will create a motion relation that can be measured (just like in the previous example) and if these 2 objects can move at least at 50% the speed of light (there's no reason why they shouldn't be able to), they will be creating a an entangled velocity relation equal (or greater) to the speed of light.
This doesn't solve Einstein's problem, but it's a cool different way of seeing it.

The problem is, relativity completely ignores the possibility of particles that don't need to accelerate, because they are already moving with light speed or faster. It only tells us, that the energy needed to accelerate past light speed rises indefinitely because of the involved relativity factor 1/(c-v). This means that it is actually possible, that there are particles in our universe, that move faster than c without the relativistic restriction, as they never ever accelerate, because they are never created or destroyed. For this theory to work however, we'd need to accept the fact, that the universe has existed forever without being created at a certain point (which in all honesty is as possible and reasonable as the big bang theory)

All Inertial frames of references observe the SAME laws of physics (including velocity of light), irrespective of their “absolute speeds." In fact "absolute speed" is completely non deterministic, nor it exerts any observable physical force to be relevant. Special relativity only makes time appear to dilate between two inertial frames of reference (e.g. F0 and F1) when they part away RELATIVE to each other. Observers at F0 of F1 would see each other’s time slowing to a grinding halt by the same amount when they part away with speeds approaching c (the speed of light).
Imagine two frame of references, F1 and F2 parting away from F0 in exactly the opposite direction at 90% of c. Observers in F0 and F1 pair would experience same time dilation of each other’s clock as observer in F0 and F2. However observers in F1 and F2 pair have their inertial frames of reference parting away at speeds exceeding c (180%). They obviously cannot use the limited scope of Special Relativity equations, but that doesn't mean they cannot even part away faster than speed of light. Only within our Hubble horizon we cannot OBSERVE relative speeds crossing c (extremely hard) – other parts of universe/galaxies are speeding away -- at any inertial speed -- without caring about the observable relative velocity limit of c between any two frames of references.

Black holes.

So, the event horizon is the point at which light can no longer escape the gravity of the black hole. Meaning that if you are at the event horizon, you need to be traveling faster than the speed of light to escape that point. The deeper you go, the faster you need to go to escape.

Theoretically, if you had a ship that could withstand the gravitational pull of the black hole, and some incredibly advanced device to cancel the gravity from effecting the people with in. Or a ship that was an unmanned space craft. You send it towards the black hole. As it gets closer and closer, it starts to speed up. Eventually it would reach a point where it's traveling at the speed of light due to the extreme gravity. Fire some rockets, and you might be able to move faster.

Now some might say "That wouldn't work. The speed of light would be terminal velocity!". Well here's the thing. No one knows what really happens inside a black hole. All we have is speculation, and theories. For all we know, laws of physics could start to break down inside such high gravity, enough so that objects could reach speeds higher than the speed of light as we know it.

The EPR experiment performed by Alan Aspect in France in the 1980's where two detectors 13 meters apart measured the spins of photons emitted from calcium atoms. This experiment introduced the concept of quantum entanglement, where two atoms are vibrating coherently without being in physical contact with each other like they are connected in some way. The experiment showed that some information (like direction of spin) can be known faster than the speed of light using probability which agreed with the quantum theory. This is worth a mention when discussing the speed of light. This information is random and therefore rather useless, but there has been some advances in quantum teleportation and quantum computers using this idea of quantum entanglement.

I think these explanations may miss the point of why light is a speed limit.  Relativity isn't concerned about whether the physical properties of mass can handle the force, it says that the laws of physics are the same in all frames of reference so even if you were going .9 speed of light,  all light would be traveling at the speed of light.  If you built a giant spaceship that could travel at .6C and then a small ship that can travel the same speed and then flew both.  First the large one goes then the small one goes inside the big one or accelerates off it.  The large ship will be going .6C relative to us, and the small one will go .6 relative to the big one in the same direction, but space and time will change to make it so that the second ship is moving slower than C relative to us.  At least that is my understanding.

If I am traveling in a spaceship and my speedometer says 2 times the speed of light, which is totally possible, then I am traveling 2 times the speed of light to me. Time will seem normal to me, however not so to the outside world. To the inertial frame of reference outside my spaceship, I will always be traveling slower than light speed, but the clocks in my spaceship will seem to run slower to the stationary observer. This is just standard relativistic time dilation. It also comes with a corresponding increase in my spaceship's mass. I can pump more and more energy into my propulsion system and accelerate well past the speed of light; to me, but will just make my clocks run slower and slower to this stationary observer.

I wonder if someone can correct my thinking here and show me where I'm going wrong.

We launch a space craft from Earth at half the speed of light (somehow).  On board is another space craft which then launches and travels away from the first at half the speed of light.  Then a third launches from the second and does the same.  The final destination is one light year away from Earth.

Now, my thinking is that the people in mission control back on Earth would perceive the third craft moving faster than the speed of light, but that would just be their perception.  The second and third spacecraft would arrive at the target at different times according to the destination's wall clock, but the people on board each craft would have experienced one year of journey time.

If my thinking is correct, and it might not be, the perceived travel time would be consistent with travelling at the speed of light for the people riding on crafts 2 and 3, although the people waiting at the destination would welcome them at a different local time.

I think the correct phrase is "information can't travel faster than the speed of light", rather than the speed limit referring to the objects themselves, but if the people on craft 3 have a message from Earth then wouldn't that get delivered faster than a laser beam from Earth could have sent it?

I suppose the experiment would be that a laser signal is sent to the to the destination saying "we are on our way."  We then wait a year for the message to arrive and then launch the first spacecraft.  The target would receive the signal and then start their timer.  If craft 3 arrived before a year of local time had passed then yay.  I expect the travellers on craft 3 would experience a year of travel time regardless.

I'm not a physicist so I'm sure I'm missing something obvious here.  This is more of a question to correct the misunderstanding I must have, rather than any kind of serious proposal.

This video did a great job until the explanation of photons that hold things together.   Electric and magnetic forces are much more fundamental than photons, and you don't need to use photons to explain them.  In fact, you cannot use photons to explain them, since a photon is created from them.

However, you left an interesting bomb there at the end about galaxies moving with a speed greater than light..  With relativistic explanations, this is an impossiblility -- especially since those galaxies have mass.  But if you treat the universe as filled with some kind of field (some might say an ether..), and the field / ether is itself expanding, this works.  There is also the chance that this ether might have different constants farther away from the locality of our solar system or even galaxy, thus a allowing a faster propagating electro-magnetic wave otherwise known as a photon.

For you people saying that we can't see the things faster than light. Our eyes actually catches the thing, but it's just that our brain isn't fast enough to react the message our eyes tell it. Imagine me throwing a ball at you. If the speed of the ball is 1mph, and the speed you're running at is 3mph. Your speed is faster than the ball, right? When I throw the ball at you, and you're running away from the ball(away from me, too). Then the ball doesn't have enough speed to catch up to you, which then the ball will just keep moving forward until they touch something else, which will not be you(unless you stop)(Of course the ball will lose energy and fall onto the ground, just imagine the ball as light). But if you're running from my left to my right(NOT running AWAY from me). When I throw the ball out before you run. That'll make you run into the ball and then it'll bounce back to me(in chances)(Just imagine two cars driving at different speed, but they sometimes do run into each other in a crossroad(car accident)) . Of course I'm not just throwing one ball. I am throwing tons of them(like a machine gun firing bullets). And when the ball went pass me and I didn't catch it. It doesn't mean that I will never get a chance to catch it. If the ball moves slower, then it might gives me a change to catch the ball. So when the object is moving in front of you and not away from you, if you use a higher fps camera and a computer. Then you actually can see the object.

One reference frame being as good as any other, the stars are seen moving about the room in a circle, apparently going faster than light. The required energy, and fictitious mass required to sustain such a speed would of course impose a requirement upon the distant stars for a significant increase in mass, and resultant time dialation, the intense tidal effects off which will be felt as centripetal force, which also happens to be a fictitious force. well.. any speed or speed limit is relative. including light because it is a universal speed limit, It cant possibly be a constant. because then however fast you go, the speed of light is C faster than you(C being the speed of light). this mean that to a person watching you move at high speeds, either light speeds up, or the time that the light takes to travel the distance it otherwise would have travelled if you were moving at the same speed to slow down. this is basically time travel. so to travel at the speed of light means to essentially freeze time. this would of course only be possible in theory. to move at the speed of light(which is known to be a constant), we would need to move so fast that light would not be able to catch up. however fast a object is moving, light is moving at C faster than that object. But isn't the speed of light relative to the position of another object? What exactly determines 'the speed of light'. Imagine a universe with only 2 objects in it. They are both moving toward each other at 1/2 the speed of light. However, from object 1's perspective it is not moving at all, and it perceives it is in the center of the universe. It perceives object 2 moving towards it at light speed. The same goes for object 2 from its position. Adding more objects does not change this, because each object can view itself as being in the center of the universe.

There is no limit to how fast the universe can expand, says physicist Charles Bennett of Johns Hopkins University. Einstein's theory that nothing can travel faster than the speed of light in a vacuum still holds true, because space itself is stretching, and space is nothing. @adhik madhav: Photon mass is zero. It can't travel at any speed except the speed of light. It can't travel at half the speed of light and accelerate, for example. Since they are always moving, they'd always have infinite mass, if what you're thinking were true.

@that christian guy: There's no real "actually going". What Einstein showed was that speed is always relative to something else. Say you're on a train moving 100mph relative to the ground. If you're walking at 2 mph forward, you are moving 2 mph relative to the train, but 102 mph relative to the ground. Both are accurate. It just depends on your frame of reference. The absolute speed limit is 299,792,458 m/s. in all reference frames.

I know of one thing that can transfer information faster than the speed of light that being: quantum information; specifically, the quantum state of electrons.
We know that electrons in the same orbital can only exist in one of the two spin-states; and that these electrons exist in what is called "quantum entanglement," which in simple terms means: knowing the spin-state of one electron immediately reveals the spin-state of the other (wiki or google should be able to expound more on this).
If we were able to pull these electrons apart from another (which can be done by bombarding the atom with photons) and they were to remain in quantum entanglement. Then if we were to pull these electrons apart farther than 3x10^8m, then identifying the state of one electron should immediately reveal information about the other electron 3x10^8m away; much faster than if that information had to travel via a photon.

Conclusion: Quantum information can travel faster than the speed of light? Yes/No/Thoughts?

To clear things up really, matter cannot move faster than lightspeed, but space itself can. Read about the space-time continuum on wikipedia. Good information, despite being complicated.

An 'Alcubierre Drive' would create the illusion of faster than light travel. The ship does not move at all in relation to the space around it, but the drive expands and contracts space itself behind the ship and in front of it. There is a limit to how fast 'things' can travel in space, but the ripples and effects of space ITSELF can 'move' Infinitely fast. This 'wave' could push the ship along at speeds in excess of 10c. Of course however there is a catch. To expand space behind the ship, 'Negative Energy' is requred. Say, an object with the mass of Jupiter in front of the ship, and an object with the mass of 'negative' Jupiter behind it. This would create the illusion of movement, whereas the ship will technically not move at all. Just the space behind it. But we currently have no way of synthesising negative energy, let alone if it can exist or not. The best bet for now is negative pressure from quantum tunnelling effects to create less 'pressure' in a volume of space, this arising from the 'Casimir Effect'. Really complicated stuff, but certainly worth checking out if you're interested in that stuff.

My understanding of special relativity is very basic, but as I understand it, things traveling at the speed of light still appear to be travelling at the speed of light, regardless of your frame of reference. Why then would the tip of the hypothetical tether run into problems? The force-carrying particles would still appear to be traveling at the speed of light, regardless of the speed of the tether.

The tether thing: The practical reasons are not the point.

The non-trivial reason why this scenario will not reach the speed of light is that as the tethers extend the entire system slows down (conserving angular momentum). As the ends of the tethers reach relativistic speeds, their relativistic mass increases. And as the relativistic mass increases the entire system has to slow down more and more to conserve angular momentum. And as the system slows down, the tips of the tethers slow down!

A few rather complicated questions with these assumptions.
 
Radio waves are photons of a particular energy state.
Radio waves can be manipulated in different ways.
AM = Amplitude Modulation
FM = Frequency Modulation
Photons have characteristics that allow them to behave as a wave and as a particle.
Photons traveling as a wave follow a wave pattern commonly called a sine wave.
The amplitude and frequency of this wave can be measured and observed on an oscilloscope.
The amplitude and frequency of this wave can be altered.

Presumption.
A photon travels from point "A" to point "B" in a straight line and it travels at the speed of light to make this journey.

In order for a photon to follow the sign wave of it's amplitude to reach it's straight line destination at the speed of light, does it not have to exceed the speed of light. Because the distance along the wave is greater than the straight line distance.

Almost every "You can't go faster than the speed of light" video I have ever seen is extremely closed-minded. Ever since the mid-nineties and the proposal of Alcubierre dive, it's been fairly obvious that superluminal travel is quite possible. The key is not in accelerating the particles -- a good warp drive would impart no force whatsoever. Instead, the solution is moving the space the particles are occupying. Since inertia is a property of matter and does not appear to be a property of space, if a way could be found to move space itself, the "speed limit of the universe" would be circumvented.

Think of it this way: you're trying to drive down a road. The unbreakable rules of the road say "vehicles must not exceed 60 miles per hour in speed on this road." Unfortunately, the distance you need to travel and the time you have to do it in require that you move at 120 miles per hour. The warp drive solution to this dilemma is to simply chisel out a section of road (with your car on it) and move that piece of the road at 120 mph. Your car remains stationary (speaking relatively now), but to an observer, "you" (the car-road-driver unit) are actually going 120 mph. But the rules remain unbroken: your car is moving exactly zero miles per hour on the road. There are no rules as to how fast the road can move with a car on it.

Repeat this process 10 or 11 times, each train only going .1C and from the view of a person standing next to the track, the topmost train will be traveling at light speed, while perspective wise passengers at each level only see an immediate .1C difference between themselves and the trains above and below. How about we ditch the whole question and just make something practically exceed the speed of light without actually exceeding the speed of light? Compress a very small sliver of space in front of an object, likely a spaceship, allow it to return to normal once you've passed through it (which likely would happen automatically), and you're not travelling as far. If you compress the millimetre in front of your ship into a nanometre than you'd only need to reach about 300m/s to be superluminal in practice, although in reality you aren't go any faster and you only carry the same energy. A one light-year trip is now only about ten million kilometres, and that's a much easier distance to travel and at 1km/s (really slow for a spaceship) you'd get there in about four months, and at a more reasonable 10km/s (not as slow for a spaceship, but still slower than one could expect) it'd be less than two weeks. We could reach Proxima Centauri in about two months. I see no reason why this wouldn't work if we managed to find a way to precisely compress tiny amounts of space.

Lets think about this experiment, you have a light bulb emitting photons in the speed of light in all directions, meaning that relatively to the bulb every single photon is moving at the same speed, but what happens if we change the focus to one of the photons? Then the light bulb would be seemingly traveling away from the photon at the speed of light and a photon opposite to the would be traveling at twice the speed of light. How is that possible? Well the answer is actually quite interesting, because the two photons are relatively moving from each other in over the speed of light, the information about the very existence of the other one doesn't reach it. I have always had a theory about the speed of light that my dad told me to ponder when i was younger. Speed is relative. Looking at the sun for example, the photons coming from the sun are going the speed of light, relative to the sun.

However, the photons coming out of one side are going TWICE the speed of light relative to the photons coming out of the other side of the sun.

You could also think about it like this. Shine two laser pointers at each other and turn them on. The photons coming from the laser pointers are traveling at the speed of light. But the photons are passing each other at twice that speed because they are traveling in opposite directions.

Also ponder this. The sun itself is hurdling through the universe, I'm not sure at what speed but I'm sure it is because our solar system revolves around the center of the Milky Way. So the photons that are be emitted by the sun in the same direction are going faster than the speed of light because they also have the speed of the sun traveling. Much like throwing a ball at 20mph out of a car traveling 20mph so you get a net speed of 40mph.

Some scientists are now finding out that light travels at different speeds depending on the direction it's going.  It has been theorized that light can get from a star trillions of miles away to earth almost instantly.  You may say, "That's not possible, scientists have calculated the speed of light with a few different methods."  But the problem is, those methods have issues.  For example, scientists have shot light through a spinning disc and the faster the disc goes, the less light gets through, so scientists can predict relatively accurately how fast the speed of light is going.  Here's the problem.. there are still forces that we still don't know about in our universe.  We are still learning about dark matter.  More than likely, the spinning disc is producing more energy the faster it goes and that energy absorbs all the light.. so no wonder the light isn't making it through the disc.  So, thats not really a good method.  There are many different methods, but a lot of them have several issues.. so we really don't know as much as we thought we did about the speed of light.  I don't disagree with "nothing can go faster than the speed of light" but I do not believe we have truly figured out what the speed of light even is.

Tachyons, while theoretical, can travel only at speeds faster than light's (sort of).

Any particle with negative mass would be traveling backwards in time, if you could stand completely still and detect a tachyon, it could be traveling to apparent speeds up to 2 times c. However, it would be an illusion, while standing still you're travelling through time (4th axis) at c, and the tachyon would be a variation of space in a given negative time, therefore a speed of -c (again in the 4th axis)... but the "2c" speed would only be perceived because of the illusion that when we're standing still we aren't moving at all. This speed is the main reason while we couldn't detect them yet, by the way.

As we move back in time (or farther away) in the universe the expansion accelerates (seems to). There comes a point where the galaxies would appear to be moving faster than c. V=d/t.  What happens with the galaxies is that while the galaxy is moving from point A to B, The space between A and B is expanding. Make t= 1 sec. When it reaches B, A is much further away than when the interval had started. The galaxy didn't actually move through space faster than c, space expanded.

Imagine a 100 yard race track, and you can run it in 10 seconds. Now imagine while you're running that the starting line is pulled back to 1000 yards. You still took 10 seconds but where you end and where you started are 10 times further apart. Make sense ?

And, for the spinning wheel with retractable "wings" - Derek, do a simple experiment, in fact, this experiment can do anyone at home. You sit down on an office chair, that one that allows you to spin on it, spin it while sitting on it, put two weights into your hands(best is 2-5kg, could be 2l of water in a PET bottle) and straighten your hands while holding the weight. You'll see something interesting. SPOILER: you will start spinning slower and when you retract your arms, you'll spin the original speed. It is due to a simple law - conservation of momentum, more precisely, angular momentum. So the "wingy" or "sticky" wheel would need some additional force to keep it rotating at the same speed as the sticks, wings or whatever were reaching further. Hence, you would accelerate the massive tip of those sticks to the speed of light. I think you missed this one.

HYPOTENUSE=GAMMA*C
SPEED OF LIGHT VERTICALLY=C
SPEED OF THE TRAIN HORIZONTALLY=C
GAMMA*GAMMA*C*C=C*C+C*C
GAMMA*GAMMA=2
GAMMA=SQUARE ROOT(2)

IF THE FACTOR GAMMA IS BIGGER THAN SQUARE ROOT(2) THEN THE SPEED OF LIGHT IS OVERCOME.
WHEN THE SPEED OF THE TRAIN IS 1.5 C THEN :
GAMMA*GAMMA*C*C=(3/2)*(3/2)*C*C+C*C
GAMMA*GAMMA*C*C=(9/4)*C*C+C*C
GAMMA*GAMMA*C*C=(13/4)*C*C
GAMMA*GAMMA=13/4
GAMMA=SQUARE ROOT(13/4)=1.8027756377

It's not impossible to go faster than light.  It is impossible to go faster than light through space.
Two examples of exceeding 300,000 m/s.
One happened right after the big bang, inflation occurred at greater than the speed of light.  So space, can move faster than light.
Two: (admittedly theoretically but still possible) have some ultra-futuristic ship with incredible power and shields.  Fly into the event horizon of a black hole.  That area of space is moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light.   You enter that area and accelerate to .9c with the flow.   This, combined with the fact that your moving through fast moving space means that, relative to the space you entered, you have moved faster than light.   And, if the ship was capable of escaping the event horizon, it could exit before it entered.

Actually, the most fascinating proposition for FTL travel I've come across, barring wormholes, is distortion of spacetime, so that one can appear to be travelling faster than light to an outside observer, while your actual velocity is under the speed of light, as described by the Alcubierre warp drive. Some experiments are being conducted by Nasa in the form of the White-Juday Interferometer experiment, where they are attempting to use the Casimir effect to create such a space warp, albeit a microscopic one. They did recently release some preliminary results that were indicative of an actual space warp, but they were concerned about possible external interference creating the signal they detected, so successor experiments are being prepped. I look forward to the results they come up with, be they positive or negative.

let's stick to your example of the laserbeam flicking across the surface of the moon. now lets place one photon detector (A) on one side, another (B) on the other side. we then set up the laser pointer in such a way, that it will flick across the moon at a random time in the future and that it will definitely trigger BOTH detectors - first A then B. now an observer at B would know when A has been triggered - faster than a direct signal from A could reach him. so: did information actually travel faster than light here?

There are a couple of ways you can theoretically travel vast distances in less time than light but without breaking the light speed barrier. Both work by manipulating space/time (S/T). The best known, Warp drive works by contracting S/T in front of the direction of motion and expand it to the rear, as it's S/T that's moving and that can expand faster than light speed, and it's not actually your vessel that's exceeding light speed, Einstein is a happy bunny. Or you could use a wormhole, you do this by bending S/T in half bringing your start point and end point closer together and then create a bridge between the two points effectively creating a short cut and cutting out all that messy distance business in between.
Now, both these methods work like dynamite on paper, in fact people have sat down, done the math and papers have been published on these subjects. The only real downside is practical application. How do you stretch and contract space/time or bend it in half and drill a hole through reality? Well according to Hawking (why does Hawking always know about this sh*t?) you'll need exotic material and quite a LOT of energy to achieve our desired effect.... I think we can say that we're quite a few years away from building star gates and warp drives.

So with a little fun math I calculated the overall maximum speed of a person standing on the planets surface.

If we calculate the speed of the earth's rotation .5km/s
Plus the speed that it's moving around our star 30km/s
And then we add the speed our star circles the milkyway 250km/s
And then our galaxy's speed relative to our local galaxy cluster 300km/s and then add the relative speed our supercluster is moving 600km/s
We get 1,180.5km/s vs the speed of light 300,000km/s.
That means that even with a once in a 250million year advantage given by the universe it's self, we are still only moving .39% the speed of light at best. Even with our fastest construct voyager is only moving at 17.5km/s and while that is ridiculously fast it barely bumps us up to .4% the speed of light and that's rounding up.

Since the speed of light HAS a definition, it is something that we can calculate, thus a finite number (though that number seems to vary by different factors), why CAN'T we go past a speed of a finite number?  This question might seem odd, but let me say it in another way. Our universe can not be infinitely divided.  The minimum interval of length possible is called a plank length (1.616199X10^-35 meters) and the minimum interval of time is called plank time (5.39106X10-44 seconds).  The speed of light is one plank length per plank time.  Thus, you would need to have an object exist in two places at once, or two times at once, or have the ability to jump over regions of space time, in order to exceed that speed.

this is an incredibly simple problem, everyone else is trying to make things GO as fast as light, when you dont have to do that at all, in fact, it is infinitely (and i do mean that literally, see video) easier to just GET somewhere faster than light could.

For instance, wormholes; if the two points in space were far enough apart, but side by side due to a worm hole, or a tesseract, you could simply walk there, go less than the speed of light, and get there faster. Exiting this universe into a higher dimension, and coming back somewhere else, would take you somewhere faster than light, but not go faster than light.

Likewise, if you use the current hyperdrive formula for traveling faster than light, and essentially cut off your area of space from the rest of space, create a negative spatial pressure in front of you, travel between space to wherever you are going, and then turn off the engine, it might take more or less time than light would, but it would be near instantaneous to your experience, because your area of space would exist separately from the rest of the universe, and time wouldnt pass due to relativity.

While I agree that it would be impossible for us to create any sort of contraption that would either go the speed of light or propel an object at the speed of light, it is likely that there are still many objects that have, and currently are, not only naturally reaching the speed of light, but also exceeding this universal "speed limit".

Though much of historical science would strongly refute it, matter can feasibly be accelerated to the speed of light, though it would require an immense amount of energy, though not quite infinite, applied over a considerable length of time, and, as you stated, any molecular bonds (and perhaps even Intramolecular bonds) will be shattered when light speed is reached.

Achieving the cosmic speed limit is quite simple in theory. To my knowledge, it only really occurs in and around the objects we know as "black holes". As you probably know, matter orbiting a supermassive black hole accelerates as it falls toward the event horizon, achieving a speed of nearly, but not quite, the speed of light just prior to reaching the point of no return. 

After this, not very much is known about what happens to the matter and many seem to assume that the matter simply breaks the laws of gravitation and physics and either becomes part of the singularity without any in-between process, or ceases to accelerate after reaching this point although the applied force has increased.

I suggest that no laws are broken at the event horizon, but that matter continues to accelerate toward the singularity along its current course. This would mean that the event horizon is not the place where some unknown "event" occurs, but only the point at which falling matter has exceeded the speed of light and from where no light can possibly escape since it would require a force greater than that required to move at the speed of light to accelerate away from the singularity at that proximity.

If an object must move faster the speed of light to remain stationary in the ergosphere, then, if not being propelled outward by any force, how fast is it being pulled in by the time it reaches the event horizon?
