Imagine a pair of scissors with blades extending from here to the moon. Now close the scissors. The matter of the blades is hardly moving, but the point where the two blades intersect may travel faster than c. What is moving faster than c is a geometric relationship, not matter, so the speed limit does not apply. We would not be able to perceive it moving that fast because the light providing the information about the geometric relationship travels only at c. The blades would appear to curve simply because the light conveying the information of their movement can't get back faster.

There is an interesting hypothesis that has some, more or less credible, experimental evidence. Tunnelling is a phenomenon that absolutely happens in which a particle, e.g. an electron, physically moves through a short distance in a material in the process of passing though an "energy barrier". In tunneling, the particle does not have enough energy to get "over" the barrier, but somehow it does. This is a tricky concept, but, the interface between two materials can present an energy barrier to particles trying to get from one material to another. That "barrier" can occupy a physical distance of many nanometers, up to more than a micron. 
The interesting bit is that the particles seem to get through that distance in zero time. This has been measured (I have the reference someplace). Others have shown that microwave photons can be excited to tunnel at superluminal speeds. These are very difficult experiments, and the experimenters are just human so maybe they messed up, but there is reason to consider the possibility that particles with mass, as well as massless photons too, can exceed the speed of light in a tunnelling event. 
In any case, if the big-bang hypothesis has any merit, there are certainly conditions under which mass and energy can move at substantially infinite speeds.

To Gerard:  Angular momentum is a better explanation, IMO.  It has to be constant if there isn't a change in mass, but in order for it to get wider and still have the same momentum, it would have to slow down, since there is a component describing distance from the center.  It goes back to the ice skater.  When the ice skater's arms are close in, the spin is faster.  When the arms are further out, the spin is slower.  

So without putting any more energy into the system, the angular momentum has to be the same.  If you are trying to add energy, then all those points raised by Derek apply.

hey fun idea for anyone who finds this in the comments:  i try to think of time as the increasing amount of entropy (a high energy state in a low energy environment diffusing the energy from the high energy point to the low energy point, making and equal distribution), and the rate of entropy in an object is dependent on the difference of the energy levels at the two end of low and high, the steeper the slope the faster the rate.

now adding more energy to a system would slow it down, so the slope would not be as steep. like gravity bending space - the more gravity, more energy, less entropy, slower time. this means that the rate at which energy can diffuse would be dependent on the energy in the system, so more energy would cause time slow down, and taking away energy in large amount would make you to seem, "faster"

the thing about the speed of light that answers all of these questions about possibly breaking the speed of light quite simply: the speed of light is relative. in any frame of reference where acceleration is 0, light will always be that speed. for example, if you were to have a car going 99% the speed of light with 0 acceleration and you turned on the headlights, the lights would still move ~3.00*10^8 m/s relative to the car's speed. to break the speed of light would require acceleration. if you were to accelerate endlessly, then eventually you would go faster than light. you would have to constantly add more and more energy each time. you cannot have constant acceleration. you cannot speed up from 2.00*10^8 to 3.00*10^8 in an hour, but instead go from 2.00*10^8 to 2.01*10^8 in 10 minutes, then up to 2.10*10^8 in another 10 minutes, etc. your acceleration needs to be increasing, requiring exponential amounts of force and energy added each second to the point where you become energy, where you become light. and even then that's only hypothetical

What if you were able to artificially create gravitational fields to bend space-time while the stream of photons was being emitted?  E.g. you shine a flash light and the photons start their journey while at the same time, you are bending space along that path such that space contracts towards you, making the path of the photons shorter, thus their speed faster? No, the speed would remain constant. This is just an elaborate version of moving towards a light source, which is covered by special relativity.  If the gap between you and the light decreases, it means more photons hit you per second than when you were standing still or moving away from the light. Think Doppler-effect but with colours; blue is from contraction, red is expansion.  This is similar to moving the laser across the moon, as there is no violation occurring with the speed of each photon.

If you had a "stick" one light-year long, and moved it, would you essentially cause faster-than-light effects?  No, this is just another slinky scenario; it would not actually be feasible as propagation through the "stick" would happen slower than the speed of light.

When I have two quantum-entangled particles in a superposition, and I measure one of them, then the other particle's wave function collapses instantly (i.e. faster than the speed of light). So it would seem that I can use that to transmit information faster than light.

Someone observing the other particle can deduce from the collapsing: the fact that I measured the original particle, the time at which I did that, and the state to which my particle has collapsed. And since the collapsing happens faster than light, I've transmitted those facts faster than light.

I could use a quantum computer to manipulate one particle's superposition to reveal an answer to a question when measured. For example, did Shrödinger's cat die: yes or no. So I can use that to send the answer faster than light to my friend in a galaxy far far away, who has the entangled counterpart particle.

However, this is impossible. No information can travel faster than light. Where did I go wrong?

Thing is, when you get closer and closer to the speed of light, you'll never know precisely how matter will react until we actually REACH that speed.

So maybe certain forces that keep atoms bonded together (The weak force, I think, unless that's gravity... either way) may become more powerful, or maybe the opposite, who knows.

Frankly, the only way to get to the speed of light is to see how the universe and the 'laws' of physics react to doing so.  Hell, those laws might in fact change at 90% the speed of light, but we wouldn't know it because the only things we observe going that fast are protons (and various other extremely light forms of radiation).

An example of what i'm talking about, you say that the Nanotube rope would need to be thicker at the base, but since we have never actually gotten an object like Carbon nanotubes up to that ridiculous speed, we don't know how the forces holding the atoms together reacts for that scenario.  Perhaps something changes fundamentally in the way they get held together by the 'laws' we know, and they end up being able to reach that speed without issue.  Perhaps not.

If I'm wrong on anything, feel free to correct me, i'm open to learning stuff I don't know.

What about angular momentum, as when ice skaters spin slower if they extend their arms?  10,000 rpm means a radius of 4775m to reach the speed of light.  One gram of material gives an angular momentum of about 1.4E9 kg*m*m/s.  A 100 kg sphere of a substance 1m in diameter would have to be sped to 5,570,000 rpm to attain that angular momentum.  The outer surface of that sphere would already be moving at about 35,000 km/s or over 10% lightspeed.  As you extended the tether it would slow down to 10,000 rpm when the gram at the end reached 4775m.

I've got one.  Particles accelerating toward the speed of light convert energy into mass by interacting with the Higgs field (unless I'm misunderstanding).  We know that we can create a disruption in the Higgs field to produce a Higgs boson.  Okay, so what if we could somehow create a controlled disruption in the Higgs field, like a ripple in the field moving in a specific direction.  Then anything inside that ripple would experience the speed of light being slower going against the wave, or faster moving with the wave.  So if you were going just below the speed of light, and the ripple in the Higgs field hit you from behind, you'd be going just above the normal speed of light.

Okay, here's another one.  I've heard that an object moving at near the speed of light around a high gravitational field (such as a black hole or cosmic string) moves back through time.  So what would happen if you could fly in a helix pattern around either a cosmic string or a small black hole that you brought with you?  From your own point of view, you'd still be going slower than light, but because you'd be going back in time from moving around the black hole, it would cancel out the effect of going forward in time from approaching the speed of light, and you'd reach your destination in less time that it would have taken you going at the speed of light, which would make it appear to an outside observer that you were going faster than light.  What do you think?

build a rocket that can go 99.999% the speed of light and sit in a capsule in its tip, once it reaches that speed, detach the capsule and activate its propulsion system. According to the theory of relativity everything moving at a constant speed is actually standing still relative to its frame of reference, this is why when you sit in a car, everything in the car including yourself is standing still, while the world outside is whizzing by, so anyway, using this principle we can say that when we're moving at 99.999% the speed of light, we're in fact standing still relative to the ship's frame of reference, so when we launch the capsule in the front, it'll naturally go faster than the ship itself, going faster by any amount would technically break the limit...

An example would be if you were in a train going at 150 km/h, and you then ran down the length of it at the speed of 20 km/h, but it'd only be 20 km/h relative to the train, relative to the outside world however you'd be moving at 170 km/h, faster than the train itself.

I'm not a physicist, but I've never liked the term "speed of light" when talking about the fastest that things can go. It's not like you can't go faster than light just because light has to be the fastest thing. It's that c is a universal speed limit on everything, including light. Protons, among a plethora of other particles cannot go faster than c, because c is the "Universal Speed Limit." So why do we still call it the speed of light when we want to talk about the maximum speed? It's kinda archaic and probably has something to do with how we discovered this speed limit.

If I can add one more "faster than light" that many people have probably heard of - transmission of information via quantum entanglement (i.e. the changes affecting one quantum entangled particle immediately affect it's entangled partner, regardless of the distance between them).  This does appear to be the case, but cannot transmit information faster than light because in order for it to work as a transmission medium, you need to know something about when and how the other particle was affected, which travels at the speed of light, though there is ongoing research to determine ways that this may not be a limit.
